title: Kingsbridge and Bowcombe Creek Walking Route

images.title: Tony Teperek / Kingsbridge Estuary, Kingsbridge
images.caption: Looking almost due North up the estuary towards the town centre from the embankment by the Crabshell Inn, Tacket Wood on the opposite bank.

images.title: Martin Bodman / Kingsbridge: Kingsbridge Estuary
images.caption: Kingsbridge Estuary With the tide out. The towns lower public car park is on the right, where there is a preserved limekiln. In the 19th century sailing vessels would have tied up at the quay here, bringing limestone and culm to burn in the kiln

images.title: Derek Harper / Bowcombe Creek
images.caption: Bowcombe Creek. Looking towards and down the creek from Kingsbridge Footpath 6, across a side valley with High House Farm. The main Kingsbridge Estuary is on the right. Not the best time of day for this view, taken into the sun.

images.title: Derek Harper / Head of Bowcombe Creek
images.caption: Head of Bowcombe Creek. Taken from the western top end of Kingsbridge Footpath 9 on Shindle Mill Hill, with the footbridge at the head of the creek that marks normal tidal limit.

images.title: South Hams : Bowcombe Creek by Lewis Clarke, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The southern end of Bowcombe Creek on a crystal clear summer day.

images.title: Seats in Kingsbridge by Philip Halling, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Seats in Kingsbridge. A view of the pleasant town centre of this market town.

description: Enjoy a circular walk to the lovely Bowcombe Creek from the popular market town of Kingsbridge in the South Devon AONB. There's much to enjoy in the area with lovely views of the boats in the estuary and nice green lanes with lots of wildflowers and butterflies to look out for. The route starts in the town centre and passes through the town before heading east through the countryside to the Bowcombe Creek. The creek is a great place for bird watching with herons, egrets, redshank and shelduck to look out for. Buzzards and Peregrine Falcon are often seen overhead. After exploring the creek the route then follows other footpaths back through the countryside to the town. You can extend your walking in the area by heading south and enjoying a circular walk along the Salcombe and Kingsbridge Estuary. Here you will find reed beds, mudflats and eelgrass beds supporting an abundance of wildlife on the estuary. Dolphins, seals and basking sharks can all be seen from the paths.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Head to the Crab Shell Inn for some refreshments after your walk. The pub is located in a great location on the quayside with fine views of the estuary. They do excellent seafood and also are well known locally for their excellent pizzas. You can find the pub at a postcode of TQ7 1JZ for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The area is nice for dog walking and the Crab Shell Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head south and you can try the Salcombe and Bolt Head Circular Walk which visits some lovely cliff tops and woodland near the town. A few miles to the north there's the worthy village of Loddiswell where you can enjoy some fine trails through the River Avon Valley. Near here there's also the climb to the viewpoint and Iron Age Hillfort at Blackdown Rings and the pretty riverside village of Aveton Gifford to explore. For more walking ideas in the area see the Devon Walks page.

display_address: Prince Of Wales Road, Dodbrooke, Kingsbridge, West Alvington, South Hams, Devon, England, TQ7 1DX, United Kingdom
